Musa Advises Dorm Shift
Advisers Proposed
For Better Dorms
By KEN NOBEL
A solution- to the problems currently facing the
D.S.R.C. has been suggested by Mark Musa, who has
served for two years as a counselor in the dormitories.
Citing as an example the recent D.S.R.C. decisions
concerning the "instigators" of the riot two weeks ago,
Musa pointed out that the judiciary activities of the council have placed the group in a very unpleasant position,
and that the D.S.R.C. should not be forced to judge their
fellow students in this way.
As an alternative he proposes that the D.S.R.C., aftet
conferring with the student body, ask Dean Shaffer to
assign a graduate student to live in each dorm house to
handle these situations. This would relieve the D.S.R.C.
of the responsibilities which have resulted in so much ili
will in the past.

Morrill Disappointed
With regard to the outcome
of last week's riot, President Pete
Abeson stated that Dean Morrill
was "quite disappointed with the
final decision of the Council."
He added, however, that the
Dean would abide by the Council's decision.
At last week's hearings ten
boys were convicted of having
thrown firecrackers, lighting
flares, letting the air out of Dean
Shaffer's tires and committing
other "serious" offenses.
Social Probation
Of the ten boys one was put
on strict social probation. The
other boys were put on strict
social probation, confined to the
library on week nights; letters
were also sent to the parents of
these boys.
DSRC President Abeson, commenting on the penalties, stated
that only the noisiest and most
conspicious offenders had been
singled out for punishment. He
added that the DSRC had 1

selected the names of thirteen
suspected violaters but that upon further inquiry it was revealed that three of them were
innocent. "All ten of the other
boys confessed so it was not
really a hearing." he added.

Folksy Folly
We were astonished beyond belief this week to learn
that the abortive Bob Gibson folk music concert cost the
undergraduate students the criminal sum of $1,000. By
our calculations, considering that the concert was attended
by only abou', 80 people, it works out to the incredible
figure of $12.50 a head.
The concert appears to be the product of sheer folly
and incompetent planning by the three sponsoring class's
officers. They were simply duped. We are unable to
understand how a secondary artist rated a fee equivalent
to that paid to such first-rate performers as Nina Simone
and Odetta, both of whom played before near capacity
crowds in concerts which were nothing short of booming
successes. These two concerts were the result of highly
competent and experienced planning and promotion by
Dr. Chester Wickwire. The Gibson concert lacked all
these factors.
First, the performance lacked adequate and accurate
publicity. The posters went up only a short time before
the actual date, and it was billed as a "jazz concert," Bob
Gibson's name being relegated to much smaller type. Second, there was no reason in the world why it shouldn't
have been held out in the bright sun as originally planned.
Finally, the transferral of the concert to one of the local
fraternity houses is of questionable validity in a class
sponsored affair.
In any case, the $1,000 is already spent and gone. We
only hope this is not an indication of the type of incompetence and bungling to be expected next year from our
student leaders. $1,000 could have bought a great deal
of much needed facilities on this campus, acknowledged
for its deficiency in undergraduate provisions.

A Second Proposal
The slogan on the Homewood campus this year has
been Apathy, and rightly so. But the solution to this problem does not lie in recriminations, nor is it the fault of the
Admissions Office. After all, how excited can a student
be in a class election or SC election. The only issues are
ones of personality.
As Hegel pointed out in his Philosophy of Right, for
effective government there must be a mediating body between the citizen and the government. And this body is
the political party.
Assuming Hopkins student government had political
parties, there can be no doubt that the student would have
more interest in his own government. In this case there
would be legitimate issues in the government, and, more
importantly, each student would have the opportunity to
become involved in his government through his party.
To establish such parties would be quite easy. Representation in the student council would be by party only.
Each party would receive delegates in proportion to its
total vote,-and delegates would be named from lists submitted by the party in advance.
Thus the student would not only be voting for individuals but also for parties and platforms. The popularity
polls we now have would be substituted for by issues and
ideas.
At the moment the individual student is virtually
powerless to effect any change in student government.
The best he can do is to vote for those men whom he
hopes will in some way agree with his views. But in a
party system the student could vote for the party which
best represents his beliefs and ideas.
In essence, the formation of political parties on the
Hopkins campus would have three beneficial results. The
first is that elections would no longer be the farce that
they are now. Secondly, the student body would have
the opportunity to actually participate in and determine
the course of their own government. And finally, the major
cause for apathy, the warranted lack of interest in an
impersonal and remote government, would be removed.

The latest in contests: College student entrants
aspiring to win the $1000 first prize in the Martex Scholarship Award Color Contest are asked to submit a "25-word
statement on the color they prefer in their bathroom, and

OLD GRADS NEVER DIE
In just a matter of weeks many of you will be graduating—
especially seniors.
You are of course eager to go out in the great world where
opportunities are limitless and deans nonexistent. At the same
time your hearts are heavy at the thought of losing touch with
so many classmates you have come to know and love.
It is my pleasant task today to assure you that graduation
need not mean losing touch with classmates; all you have to do
is join the Alumni Association and every year you will receive
a bright, newsy, chatty bulletin, chock full of information about
all your old buddies.
,
'
.•,

Oh, what a red-letter day it is at my house, the day the
Alumni Bulletin arrives! I cancel all my engagements, take the
phone off the hook, dismiss my chiropractor, put the ocelot
outside, and settle down for an evening of pure pleasure with
the Bulletin and (need I add?) a good supply of Marlboro
Cigarettes.
Whenever I am having fun, a Marlboro makes the fun even
more fun. That filter, that flavor, that pack or box never fails
to heighten my pleasure whether I am watching the television
or playing buck euchre or knitting an afghan or reading Mad
or enjoying any other fun-filled pursuit you might name—except, of course, spearfishing. But then, how much spearfishing
does one do in Clovis, New Mexico, where I live?
But I digress. Let us return to my Alumni Bulletin and let
me quote for you the interesting tidings about all my old friends
and classmates:
Well, fellow alums, it certainly has been a wing-dinger of a
year for all us old grads! Remember Mildred Cheddar and
Harry Camembert, those crazy kids who always held hands in
Econ II? Well, they're married now and living in Clovis, New
Mexico, where Harry rents spearfishing equipment and Mildred
has just given birth to a lovely 28-pound daughter, her second
in four months. Nice going, Mildred and Harry!
Remember Jethro Brie, the man we voted most likely to succeed? Well, old Jethro is still gathering laurels! Last week he
was voted "Motorman of the Year" by his fellow workers in
the Duluth streetcar system. "I owe it all to my brakeman,'!
said Jethro in a characteristically modest acceptance speech.
Same old Jethro!
Probably the most glamorous time of all us alums was had by
Francis Macomber last year. He went on a big game hunting
safari all the way to Africa! We received many interesting post
cards from Francis until he was, alas, accidently shot and killed
by his wife and white hunter. Tough luck, Francis!
Wilma "Deadeye" Macomber, widow of the late beloved
Francis Macomber, was married yesterday to Fred "Sureshot",
Quimby, white hunter, in a simple double-ring ceremony in
Nairobi. Good luck, Wilma and Fred!
Well, alums, that just about wraps it up for this year. Keep

'em flying!

01961 Max Shulman

Albee's The Zoo Story Enacted
In arnstormers Presentation
By BOB LANDAU
Those of the Hopkins community who were fortunate
enough to see the Barnstormer's
production of Edward Albee's
The Zoo Story are a much enriched group. Not only did they
witness a first-rate production,
but they also received a chance
to view the work of a young
playwright who many feel will
lead the American Theatre out
of its current commercialized
wilderness. Mr. Albee attacks an
important problem that is typical of much of America today:
the failure of people to find a
means of communication with the
another. And though The Zoo
Story may be largely allegorical
and its characters symbolic, they
are so lucidly sketched, and endowed with such crackling dialogue that the audience never
loses interest in them as characters.
"The American dream," stated
Albee in a recent interview, "is
the substitution of artificial
values for real values ... People
try so hard to escape being
touched by unpleasantness that
they wind up being unable to
feel anything or communicate
anything." With this in mind,
Albee sets his scene in Central
Park where Peter, well-to-do,
middle-aged textbook publisher
is seated on a bench, complacently reading a book. His Sunday afternoon serenity is disturbed when Jerry, a young,
shabbily dressed man abruptly
attempts to engage him in a
form of conversation. Jerry first
plumbs his background: we learn
that Peter lives in a smart neighborhood on one side of the park
with his wife, two daughters
two cats, and two parakeets. In
contrast, Jerry lives alone in a
dilapidated rooming house on
the other side of the park. Judgeing from the subjects that Jerry
talks about, one feels that he
considers himself completely
isolated from the people around
him. The crucial segment of his
dialogue is "The Story of Jerry
and the Dog" in which Jerry
tells Peter how he attempted to
placate his landlady's dog who
for some reason felt a strong
antipathy towards him. After a
daily peace offering of meat

failed to pacify the beast, Jerry
decided to poison it. But Jerry
explains to an almost hypnotized
Peter that, though he tried to
kill the dog, he was overjoyed
when it recovered, for he desperately desired to find out
what their new relationship
would amount to. The result was
a standoff, with neither showing
any affirmative or negative
emotions; nevertheless Jerry is
satisfied, for finally he has
broken down all barriers, all
pretentions, and made true contact with the dog — a situation
that he finds impossible to establish with people.
But Peter does not understand.
He finds the story strongly disconcerting. His refusal to comprehend disgusts Jerry so much
that the latter attempts to

arouse Peter out of his superficial state by physically forcing
him to react. By running himself in on a knife Peter is holding, Jerry finally manages, as
both men scream almost simultaneously to create an emotional bond with Peter—but at
the cost of his own life.

Goucher Aides—
The News Letter was very
fortunate this week in being
aided and abetted in its
journalistic endeavors by students of Goucher College. The
girls contributed to the general morale of the staff in addition to lending a touch of
Goucher dignity and refinement. We of the N-L wish to
thank them for their help.

May 22, 1911:

FIFTY YEARS AGO
An old story — Never before in the history of athletics at
Hopkins have so many victories been won in the course of a single
season ... But we should not let our past successes blind us ...
If we wish to keep the place which we have won or to rise higher
we must not abate our efforts . .. The teams must feel that the
whole student body is behind them in order that they may do
their best. The success or failure of next year's season lies largely
in the hands of the student. Our duty is manifest.
Hullabaloo again — At a class meeting last Thursday the
Sophomores decided to try to get out a Hullabaloo next year ...
For the present the editors will busy themselves trying to ascertain
how much money .they can count upon towards defraying the
expenses if the Hullabaloo is to be published.
Summer School fees — Johns Hopkins University's first summer session will have as its fee twenty-five dollars, entitling the
student to as many as three courses.

TWENTY-FIVE YEARS AGO
May 30, 1936:
June Week — A June Week crowded with social high-lights
will get under way on June 2 ... The five days of gala celebration
will feature numerous dances, two of which will stand out because
of the'presence of Jimmy Lunceford and Benny Goodman, listed
among America's top-rate dance band maestros.
"Quad Quips" — Sophomores are still waiting for that list
from the dean's office letting them know whether they will be
allowed the privilege of attending the Johns Hopkins University
for another two years—for $450 annum.
Suggestion — To Mrs. Johnson of the cafeteria: Outdoor tables
with umbrellas next year on every clear day. Also attractive waitresses instead of waiters.

Daring Maneuver Succeeds
As Students Snare Navy Goat
(Continued front Page 1)
Special Forces Group located on
the Hopkins campus.
Hour Set
Hour was set as 1 a.m. on
Thursday, May 11. However,
after arriving at the jump off
spot at the designated time the
Livestock Action Unit (or LAU)
was confronted by three major
problems.
First it was raining and certain members of the group
objected to getting wet. ,
Secondly, it was discovered
that it was impossible to saw
the padlock on the gate.
Much Manure
And finally, an abundance of
manure on the ground made
footing dangerously slippery.
At this point the LAU went
into a conference lasting to
approximately 4 a.m. held in
the, dry comfort of the get-away
car. At this conference the plans
for the operation were completely revised. By 4 the LAU was
ready to swing into action.
The fearless leader and operative two acted as the advance
guard. In order to get through
the 10 ft. fence with barbed
wire at the top and bottom, operative three held the barbed wire
up and the fearless leader
crawled underneath losing only
one pair of pants.
By this time it was milking

time at the farm and the fearless
leader was forced to pretend to
milk cows while conducting his
operations.
Stage Set
Once inside the leader sawed
through approximately 25 wires
on the fence and cut the barbed
wire at the bottom. The stage
was now set for the actual abduction.
The oriental eperative chased
the goat around the compound
and finally forced him inside his
hut. At this point the leader
climbed on the back of the goat,
operative number three grabbed a
horn, and the two of them drove
him out through the hole in
the fence into a meadow.
The LAU now deposited the
goat in the back of their getaway car (causing severe damage to the upholstery and the
command unit effected their
escape.
The goat was taken to a farm
near York, Pennsylvania and was
housed there during Thursday
and early Friday.
First Error
Meanwhile, back on the Hopkins campus the LAU made their
first major error. The fearless
leader approached Dean Shaffer
and asked him whether he
would approve exhibition of the
goat at the lacrosse game. At

informed him that the Commandant of Annapolis had discretely told him (the Dean) that,
if the goat was not returned
Navy would not meet Hopkins
in any athletic contests that
weekend.
The fearless leader was then
charged with the heavy responsibility of returning the goat as
fast as possible. Upon receipt
of this news, the fearless leader
collected his fearless group and
the goat was returned.
Complications
At this point complications
occurred. A second car followed
the LAU back to the Navy farm.
This car contained several members of a nameless (for reasons
of safety) fraternity. As soon as
the fearless commandos returned
the goat to his pen and departed,
the fearless Greeks walked in
and removed the goat from his
pen.
But unfortunately for all
groups involved, the Deans (Morrill and Shaffer) raised objections to this second abduction.
Dean Morrill now gave the LAU
and its fearless leader the responsibility for the second return of the goat. This humiliating task was carried out on Friday evening, and at long last the
Navy's poorly protected and
seemingly quite valuable goat

this point the Dean discretely safe at home.

Hopkins AAUP
Boycotts Planned
Defense Ed. Act
The Johns Hopkins Chapter
of the American Association of
University Professors has passed
and sent to Dr. Eisenhower a
motion calling for the University to refuse to participate in
the National Defense Education
Act loan program if the disclaimer affidavit is not stricken
from it.
At its May 12 meeting the
chapter passed a motion stating
(1) that the Johns Hopkins
Chapter of the AAUP is strongly
opposed to the disclaimer affidavit provision in the National
Defense Education Act (2) that
the Chapter calls upon the President and the Trustees of the
Johns Hopkins University to
indicate their opposition to the
disclaimer affidavit (3) that the
Chapter urges the University
to refuse to participate in the
National Defense Education Act
if the dislaimer affidavit is
not stricken from it.
The first two parts of the
motion were passed unanimously and the third passed on a
split vote.
Also at this meeting the chapter elected Prof. Charles Singleton of the Romance Languages
Department as its new president,
Dr. Victor G. Laties of the
Medical School as vice-president,
Prof. Stewart H. Hulse of the
Psychology Department as Secretary, and Prof. Joseph Ascheim
of the Department of Political
Economy as treasurer.

Frosh Stickmen
Finish Strongly,
Beat St. Paul'
The Frosh lacrosse team,
Which started well, sagged in
the middle of the season,finished
strongly this past week, as they
lost a squeeker to the Navy
Plebes by 11-7, and beat St.
Paul's School by a score of 4-2.
The key to the Navy game was
hustle. The Plebes, who whipped
the same Maryland frosh team
that whipped the baby Jays 156, came into the game assured
that they would quickly turn the
game into a rout. At the end of
the first quarter, a goal by Plebe
Pete Taylor, who scored 8 in the
game, made the "rout" 2-1.
Special words of praise for a
good job both in the game and
the season must go to Dave MacCool, Goalie John Beck, Homer
Schwartz, Mike Ratner, "Shoeless" Joe Hahn, Al Katcef, and
Lauren Scheffenacker. These
1)0Y5, all of whom played a fine
game, oame along very well
during the season and all of
them ought to be a big asset to
fUture Jay Lacrosse teams. Outstanding in the game were Beck,
Who made several excellent saves
and cleared better than he had
been doing all year, and SchWartz, who scored once to boost
his seasonal total to 12, tops for

the team.

Urner and Baron (1), Cameron
and Brenner (2), and Lurie
paired with Garceau or Farnham
at 2, will do battle.
The pick in this corner is Hopkins.

hustling, a team that is always
dogging their opponent whether
ahead or behind. The pixieish
(5'6", 150 pound) Allegretti put
it this way—"We know we've
got to hustle to win. We know
we don't have the stick handling
finesse of a team like Hopkins,
so we stress conditioning. And
we hustle. We're always hustling. We won today cause we
wanted it bad." The soft spoken
Senior goalie from Chicago went
on to tell of Navy's training program. "We'll run three miles
around this cemetery they've got
near the school. That's besides
wind-sprints and scrimmaging
every day."
A jubilant Roger Kiesel, Navy
mid-fielder, summed up this
team's attitude in his general
declaration to the entire lockerroom that"we can't be beat when
we're hustling."
Four packs of beer were thrown
on the floor and these were
quickly hawked up, with some
Middies dashing from the showers to get their share. That night
they would be going to a party
at the Baltimore home of Ben
Mitchell, brother of Navy attackman Tom Mitchell. Now a Naval
Academy officer was handing out
four single dollar bills to each
member for supper that evening.
One impatient Middie hollered,
"Let's go, I want my payola."
Coach Elated
Head coach Bill Bilderback
was now extending congratulations to several of his charges
and soon was joined by his
assistant Dick Corrigan, who
came strutting into the lockerroom singing "That Old Black

Magic."
Coach Bilderback,reflecting on
the triumph, was quietly enthusiastic. "It's always good to
beat Hopkins," said he.

Mr. NIFTY CLEANERS

Essays in Honor of William Foxwell Albright
Edited by G. Ernest Wright
In the past fifty
years, our knowledge
of the world of the
Bible and the ancient
Near East has been
revolutionized. This
volume records the
great leap forward in
Near Eastern studies
and honors William
Foxwell Albright, the
great American scholar who has contributed most to this
achievement.
The contributors are: John Bright, Edward F. Campbell,
Jr., Frank Moore Cross, Jr., David Noel Freedman, Albrecht Goetze, Thorkild Jacobsen, Samuel Noah Kramer,
Thomas 0. Lambdin, George E. Mendenhall, William J.
Moran, S. J., Harry M. Orlinsky, Gus W. Van Beek, John
A. Wilson, and G. Ernest Wright.
William Foxwell Albright was Director of the American
School of Oriental Research in Jerusalem, became W. W.
Spence Professor of Semitic Languages and Chairman of
the Oriental Seminary at Johns Hopkins University, from
which he retired in 1958.

Editor

Editor
Editor

Folksy Folly
We were astonished beyond belief this week to learn
that the abortive Bob Gibson folk music concert cost the
undergraduate students the criminal sum of $1,000. By
our calculations, considering that the concert was attended
by only abou', 80 people, it works out to the incredible
figure of $12.50 a head.
The concert appears to be the product of sheer folly
and incompetent planning by the three sponsoring class's
officers. They were simply duped. We are unable to
understand how a secondary artist rated a fee equivalent
to that paid to such first-rate performers as Nina Simone
and Odetta, both of whom played before near capacity
crowds in concerts which were nothing short of booming
successes. These two concerts were the result of highly
competent and experienced planning and promotion by
Dr. Chester Wickwire. The Gibson concert lacked all
these factors.
First, the performance lacked adequate and accurate
publicity. The posters went up only a short time before
the actual date, and it was billed as a "jazz concert," Bob
Gibson's name being relegated to much smaller type. Second, there was no reason in the world why it shouldn't
have been held out in the bright sun as originally planned.
Finally, the transferral of the concert to one of the local
fraternity houses is of questionable validity in a class
sponsored affair.
In any case, the $1,000 is already spent and gone. We
only hope this is not an indication of the type of incompetence and bungling to be expected next year from our
student leaders. $1,000 could have bought a great deal
of much needed facilities on this campus, acknowledged
for its deficiency in undergraduate provisions.

A Second Proposal
The slogan on the Homewood campus this year has
been Apathy, and rightly so. But the solution to this problem does not lie in recriminations, nor is it the fault of the
Admissions Office. After all, how excited can a student
be in a class election or SC election. The only issues are
ones of personality.
As Hegel pointed out in his Philosophy of Right, for
effective government there must be a mediating body between the citizen and the government. And this body is
the political party.
Assuming Hopkins student government had political
parties, there can be no doubt that the student would have
more interest in his own government. In this case there
would be legitimate issues in the government, and, more
importantly, each student would have the opportunity to
become involved in his government through his party.
To establish such parties would be quite easy. Representation in the student council would be by party only.
Each party would receive delegates in proportion to its
total vote,-and delegates would be named from lists submitted by the party in advance.
Thus the student would not only be voting for individuals but also for parties and platforms. The popularity
polls we now have would be substituted for by issues and
ideas.
At the moment the individual student is virtually
powerless to effect any change in student government.
The best he can do is to vote for those men whom he
hopes will in some way agree with his views. But in a
party system the student could vote for the party which
best represents his beliefs and ideas.
In essence, the formation of political parties on the
Hopkins campus would have three beneficial results. The
first is that elections would no longer be the farce that
they are now. Secondly, the student body would have
the opportunity to actually participate in and determine
the course of their own government. And finally, the major
cause for apathy, the warranted lack of interest in an
impersonal and remote government, would be removed.

OLD GRADS NEVER DIE
In just a matter of weeks many of you will be graduating—
especially seniors.
You are of course eager to go out in the great world where
opportunities are limitless and deans nonexistent. At the same
time your hearts are heavy at the thought of losing touch with
so many classmates you have come to know and love.
It is my pleasant task today to assure you that graduation
need not mean losing touch with classmates; all you have to do
is join the Alumni Association and every year you will receive
a bright, newsy, chatty bulletin, chock full of information about
all your old buddies.
,
'
.•,

Oh, what a red-letter day it is at my house, the day the
Alumni Bulletin arrives! I cancel all my engagements, take the
phone off the hook, dismiss my chiropractor, put the ocelot
outside, and settle down for an evening of pure pleasure with
the Bulletin and (need I add?) a good supply of Marlboro
Cigarettes.
Whenever I am having fun, a Marlboro makes the fun even
more fun. That filter, that flavor, that pack or box never fails
to heighten my pleasure whether I am watching the television
or playing buck euchre or knitting an afghan or reading Mad
or enjoying any other fun-filled pursuit you might name—except, of course, spearfishing. But then, how much spearfishing
does one do in Clovis, New Mexico, where I live?
But I digress. Let us return to my Alumni Bulletin and let
me quote for you the interesting tidings about all my old friends
and classmates:
Well, fellow alums, it certainly has been a wing-dinger of a
year for all us old grads! Remember Mildred Cheddar and
Harry Camembert, those crazy kids who always held hands in
Econ II? Well, they're married now and living in Clovis, New
Mexico, where Harry rents spearfishing equipment and Mildred
has just given birth to a lovely 28-pound daughter, her second
in four months. Nice going, Mildred and Harry!
Remember Jethro Brie, the man we voted most likely to succeed? Well, old Jethro is still gathering laurels! Last week he
was voted "Motorman of the Year" by his fellow workers in
the Duluth streetcar system. "I owe it all to my brakeman,'!
said Jethro in a characteristically modest acceptance speech.
Same old Jethro!
Probably the most glamorous time of all us alums was had by
Francis Macomber last year. He went on a big game hunting
safari all the way to Africa! We received many interesting post
cards from Francis until he was, alas, accidently shot and killed
by his wife and white hunter. Tough luck, Francis!
Wilma "Deadeye" Macomber, widow of the late beloved
Francis Macomber, was married yesterday to Fred "Sureshot",
Quimby, white hunter, in a simple double-ring ceremony in
Nairobi. Good luck, Wilma and Fred!
Well, alums, that just about wraps it up for this year. Keep

'em flying!

01961 Max Shulman

Albee's The Zoo Story Enacted
In arnstormers Presentation
By BOB LANDAU
Those of the Hopkins community who were fortunate
enough to see the Barnstormer's
production of Edward Albee's
The Zoo Story are a much enriched group. Not only did they
witness a first-rate production,
but they also received a chance
to view the work of a young
playwright who many feel will
lead the American Theatre out
of its current commercialized
wilderness. Mr. Albee attacks an
important problem that is typical of much of America today:
the failure of people to find a
means of communication with the
another. And though The Zoo
Story may be largely allegorical
and its characters symbolic, they
are so lucidly sketched, and endowed with such crackling dialogue that the audience never
loses interest in them as characters.
"The American dream," stated
Albee in a recent interview, "is
the substitution of artificial
values for real values ... People
try so hard to escape being
touched by unpleasantness that
they wind up being unable to
feel anything or communicate
anything." With this in mind,
Albee sets his scene in Central
Park where Peter, well-to-do,
middle-aged textbook publisher
is seated on a bench, complacently reading a book. His Sunday afternoon serenity is disturbed when Jerry, a young,
shabbily dressed man abruptly
attempts to engage him in a
form of conversation. Jerry first
plumbs his background: we learn
that Peter lives in a smart neighborhood on one side of the park
with his wife, two daughters
two cats, and two parakeets. In
contrast, Jerry lives alone in a
dilapidated rooming house on
the other side of the park. Judgeing from the subjects that Jerry
talks about, one feels that he
considers himself completely
isolated from the people around
him. The crucial segment of his
dialogue is "The Story of Jerry
and the Dog" in which Jerry
tells Peter how he attempted to
placate his landlady's dog who
for some reason felt a strong
antipathy towards him. After a
daily peace offering of meat

failed to pacify the beast, Jerry
decided to poison it. But Jerry
explains to an almost hypnotized
Peter that, though he tried to
kill the dog, he was overjoyed
when it recovered, for he desperately desired to find out
what their new relationship
would amount to. The result was
a standoff, with neither showing
any affirmative or negative
emotions; nevertheless Jerry is
satisfied, for finally he has
broken down all barriers, all
pretentions, and made true contact with the dog — a situation
that he finds impossible to establish with people.
But Peter does not understand.
He finds the story strongly disconcerting. His refusal to comprehend disgusts Jerry so much
that the latter attempts to

arouse Peter out of his superficial state by physically forcing
him to react. By running himself in on a knife Peter is holding, Jerry finally manages, as
both men scream almost simultaneously to create an emotional bond with Peter—but at
the cost of his own life.

Goucher Aides—
The News Letter was very
fortunate this week in being
aided and abetted in its
journalistic endeavors by students of Goucher College. The
girls contributed to the general morale of the staff in addition to lending a touch of
Goucher dignity and refinement. We of the N-L wish to
thank them for their help.

May 22, 1911:

FIFTY YEARS AGO
An old story — Never before in the history of athletics at
Hopkins have so many victories been won in the course of a single
season ... But we should not let our past successes blind us ...
If we wish to keep the place which we have won or to rise higher
we must not abate our efforts . .. The teams must feel that the
whole student body is behind them in order that they may do
their best. The success or failure of next year's season lies largely
in the hands of the student. Our duty is manifest.
Hullabaloo again — At a class meeting last Thursday the
Sophomores decided to try to get out a Hullabaloo next year ...
For the present the editors will busy themselves trying to ascertain
how much money .they can count upon towards defraying the
expenses if the Hullabaloo is to be published.
Summer School fees — Johns Hopkins University's first summer session will have as its fee twenty-five dollars, entitling the
student to as many as three courses.

TWENTY-FIVE YEARS AGO
May 30, 1936:
June Week — A June Week crowded with social high-lights
will get under way on June 2 ... The five days of gala celebration
will feature numerous dances, two of which will stand out because
of the'presence of Jimmy Lunceford and Benny Goodman, listed
among America's top-rate dance band maestros.
"Quad Quips" — Sophomores are still waiting for that list
from the dean's office letting them know whether they will be
allowed the privilege of attending the Johns Hopkins University
for another two years—for $450 annum.
Suggestion — To Mrs. Johnson of the cafeteria: Outdoor tables
with umbrellas next year on every clear day. Also attractive waitresses instead of waiters.

Daring Maneuver Succeeds
As Students Snare Navy Goat
(Continued front Page 1)
Special Forces Group located on
the Hopkins campus.
Hour Set
Hour was set as 1 a.m. on
Thursday, May 11. However,
after arriving at the jump off
spot at the designated time the
Livestock Action Unit (or LAU)
was confronted by three major
problems.
First it was raining and certain members of the group
objected to getting wet. ,
Secondly, it was discovered
that it was impossible to saw
the padlock on the gate.
Much Manure
And finally, an abundance of
manure on the ground made
footing dangerously slippery.
At this point the LAU went
into a conference lasting to
approximately 4 a.m. held in
the, dry comfort of the get-away
car. At this conference the plans
for the operation were completely revised. By 4 the LAU was
ready to swing into action.
The fearless leader and operative two acted as the advance
guard. In order to get through
the 10 ft. fence with barbed
wire at the top and bottom, operative three held the barbed wire
up and the fearless leader
crawled underneath losing only
one pair of pants.
By this time it was milking

time at the farm and the fearless
leader was forced to pretend to
milk cows while conducting his
operations.
Stage Set
Once inside the leader sawed
through approximately 25 wires
on the fence and cut the barbed
wire at the bottom. The stage
was now set for the actual abduction.
The oriental eperative chased
the goat around the compound
and finally forced him inside his
hut. At this point the leader
climbed on the back of the goat,
operative number three grabbed a
horn, and the two of them drove
him out through the hole in
the fence into a meadow.
The LAU now deposited the
goat in the back of their getaway car (causing severe damage to the upholstery and the
command unit effected their
escape.
The goat was taken to a farm
near York, Pennsylvania and was
housed there during Thursday
and early Friday.
First Error
Meanwhile, back on the Hopkins campus the LAU made their
first major error. The fearless
leader approached Dean Shaffer
and asked him whether he
would approve exhibition of the
goat at the lacrosse game. At

informed him that the Commandant of Annapolis had discretely told him (the Dean) that,
if the goat was not returned
Navy would not meet Hopkins
in any athletic contests that
weekend.
The fearless leader was then
charged with the heavy responsibility of returning the goat as
fast as possible. Upon receipt
of this news, the fearless leader
collected his fearless group and
the goat was returned.
Complications
At this point complications
occurred. A second car followed
the LAU back to the Navy farm.
This car contained several members of a nameless (for reasons
of safety) fraternity. As soon as
the fearless commandos returned
the goat to his pen and departed,
the fearless Greeks walked in
and removed the goat from his
pen.
But unfortunately for all
groups involved, the Deans (Morrill and Shaffer) raised objections to this second abduction.
Dean Morrill now gave the LAU
and its fearless leader the responsibility for the second return of the goat. This humiliating task was carried out on Friday evening, and at long last the
Navy's poorly protected and
seemingly quite valuable goat

this point the Dean discretely safe at home.

Hopkins AAUP
Boycotts Planned
Defense Ed. Act
The Johns Hopkins Chapter
of the American Association of
University Professors has passed
and sent to Dr. Eisenhower a
motion calling for the University to refuse to participate in
the National Defense Education
Act loan program if the disclaimer affidavit is not stricken
from it.
At its May 12 meeting the
chapter passed a motion stating
(1) that the Johns Hopkins
Chapter of the AAUP is strongly
opposed to the disclaimer affidavit provision in the National
Defense Education Act (2) that
the Chapter calls upon the President and the Trustees of the
Johns Hopkins University to
indicate their opposition to the
disclaimer affidavit (3) that the
Chapter urges the University
to refuse to participate in the
National Defense Education Act
if the dislaimer affidavit is
not stricken from it.
The first two parts of the
motion were passed unanimously and the third passed on a
split vote.
Also at this meeting the chapter elected Prof. Charles Singleton of the Romance Languages
Department as its new president,
Dr. Victor G. Laties of the
Medical School as vice-president,
Prof. Stewart H. Hulse of the
Psychology Department as Secretary, and Prof. Joseph Ascheim
of the Department of Political
Economy as treasurer.

Frosh Stickmen
Finish Strongly,
Beat St. Paul'
The Frosh lacrosse team,
Which started well, sagged in
the middle of the season,finished
strongly this past week, as they
lost a squeeker to the Navy
Plebes by 11-7, and beat St.
Paul's School by a score of 4-2.
The key to the Navy game was
hustle. The Plebes, who whipped
the same Maryland frosh team
that whipped the baby Jays 156, came into the game assured
that they would quickly turn the
game into a rout. At the end of
the first quarter, a goal by Plebe
Pete Taylor, who scored 8 in the
game, made the "rout" 2-1.
Special words of praise for a
good job both in the game and
the season must go to Dave MacCool, Goalie John Beck, Homer
Schwartz, Mike Ratner, "Shoeless" Joe Hahn, Al Katcef, and
Lauren Scheffenacker. These
1)0Y5, all of whom played a fine
game, oame along very well
during the season and all of
them ought to be a big asset to
fUture Jay Lacrosse teams. Outstanding in the game were Beck,
Who made several excellent saves
and cleared better than he had
been doing all year, and SchWartz, who scored once to boost
his seasonal total to 12, tops for

the team.

Urner and Baron (1), Cameron
and Brenner (2), and Lurie
paired with Garceau or Farnham
at 2, will do battle.
The pick in this corner is Hopkins.

CelebrateAfterGame

hustling, a team that is always
dogging their opponent whether
ahead or behind. The pixieish
(5'6", 150 pound) Allegretti put
it this way—"We know we've
got to hustle to win. We know
we don't have the stick handling
finesse of a team like Hopkins,
so we stress conditioning. And
we hustle. We're always hustling. We won today cause we
wanted it bad." The soft spoken
Senior goalie from Chicago went
on to tell of Navy's training program. "We'll run three miles
around this cemetery they've got
near the school. That's besides
wind-sprints and scrimmaging
every day."
A jubilant Roger Kiesel, Navy
mid-fielder, summed up this
team's attitude in his general
declaration to the entire lockerroom that"we can't be beat when
we're hustling."
Four packs of beer were thrown
on the floor and these were
quickly hawked up, with some
Middies dashing from the showers to get their share. That night
they would be going to a party
at the Baltimore home of Ben
Mitchell, brother of Navy attackman Tom Mitchell. Now a Naval
Academy officer was handing out
four single dollar bills to each
member for supper that evening.
One impatient Middie hollered,
"Let's go, I want my payola."
Coach Elated
Head coach Bill Bilderback
was now extending congratulations to several of his charges
and soon was joined by his
assistant Dick Corrigan, who
came strutting into the lockerroom singing "That Old Black

Magic."
Coach Bilderback,reflecting on
the triumph, was quietly enthusiastic. "It's always good to
beat Hopkins," said he.

Mr. NIFTY CLEANERS

Essays in Honor of William Foxwell Albright
Edited by G. Ernest Wright
In the past fifty
years, our knowledge
of the world of the
Bible and the ancient
Near East has been
revolutionized. This
volume records the
great leap forward in
Near Eastern studies
and honors William
Foxwell Albright, the
great American scholar who has contributed most to this
achievement.
The contributors are: John Bright, Edward F. Campbell,
Jr., Frank Moore Cross, Jr., David Noel Freedman, Albrecht Goetze, Thorkild Jacobsen, Samuel Noah Kramer,
Thomas 0. Lambdin, George E. Mendenhall, William J.
Moran, S. J., Harry M. Orlinsky, Gus W. Van Beek, John
A. Wilson, and G. Ernest Wright.
William Foxwell Albright was Director of the American
School of Oriental Research in Jerusalem, became W. W.
Spence Professor of Semitic Languages and Chairman of
the Oriental Seminary at Johns Hopkins University, from
which he retired in 1958.
